Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Disability Rating Scale as a Predictor of Long-term Outcome in Severe Traumatic Brain Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either erythropoietin or placebo.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included adults with severe TBI, and the study was conducted in multiple trauma centers.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either erythropoietin or placebo.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the Disability Rating Scale (DRS) as a predictor of favorable 6-month Glasgow Outcome Scale extended (GOS-E).

Method_Outcome.evidence: DRS was measured weekly from weeks 1 to 4 post-injury, and GOS-E was assessed at 6 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included outcome assessors, patients, and clinicians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of the 200 participants, 100 were randomised to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The model incorporating baseline demographic and injury severity variables with week 1 DRS had an area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 0.82, increasing to 0.88 with weekly DRS until week 4.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group.
